elements.content: Five new isomorphic coordination polymers of the Co­(II) ion, namely, {[Co2L­(bpy)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (1), {[Co2L­(pbyb)0.5(H2O)2]·3H2O} n (2), {[Co2L­(dpe)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (3), {[Co2L­(dpa)0.5(H2O)2]·2.5H2O} n (4), and {[Co2L­(dip)0.5(H2O)2]·3.5H2O} n (5) (H4L = cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4-cyclopentaneteracarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine, pbyb = 1,4-di­(pyridine-4-yl)­benzene, dpe = 1,2-di­(pyridine-4-yl)­ethane, dpa = (E)-1,2-di­(pyridin-4-yl)­diazene, and dip = 1,4-di­(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzene), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The L4– ligand maintains its original conformation of SSRR in all of these compounds, but {Co5L} n clusters show mirror coordination symmetry in 1, 2, and 4 while the clusters in 3 and 5 do not. The addition of different N-ligands can tune the distance between {Co2L} n layers and change the pore structures of the frameworks. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that 1–5 exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Five new isomorphic coordination polymers of the Co(II) ion, namely, {[Co2L(bpy)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1), {[Co2L(pbyb)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3H2O} n  (2), {[Co2L(dpe)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (3), {[Co2L(dpa)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O} n  (4), and {[Co2L(dip)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} n  (5) (H4L = cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4-cyclopentaneteracarboxylic acid, bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine, pbyb = 1,4-di(pyridine-4-yl)benzene, dpe = 1,2-di(pyridine-4-yl)ethane, dpa = (E)-1,2-di(pyridin-4-yl)diazene, and dip = 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The L4- ligand maintains its original conformation of SSRR in all of these compounds, but {Co5L} n  clusters show mirror coordination symmetry in 1, 2, and 4 while the clusters in 3 and 5 do not. The addition of different N-ligands can tune the distance between {Co2L} n  layers and change the pore structures of the frameworks. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that 1-5 exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: Five new isomorphic coordination polymers of the Co­(II) ion have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The L4 ligand maintains its original conformation of SSRR in all of these compounds, but {Co5L} n clusters show mirror coordination symmetry in 1, 2, and 4 but not in 3 and 5. Different N-ligands can tune the distance between {Co2L} n layers and change the pore structures of the frameworks. 1−5 exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Five new isomorphic coordination polymers of the Co(II) ion have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The L4 ligand maintains its original conformation of SSRR in all of these compounds, but {Co5L} n  clusters show mirror coordination symmetry in 1, 2, and 4 but not in 3 and 5. Different N-ligands can tune the distance between {Co2L} n  layers and change the pore structures of the frameworks. 1-5 exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: A large amount of attention has been widely focused on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in many areas, ranging from catalysis to surface chemistry, gas storage and separation, sensing, ion exchange, drug delivery, carbon capture, and magnetic materials. This attention is due to their unique, interesting topological structures and fascinating properties, such as facile synthesis, large surface area, and relatively high thermal stability and porosity; among these, it is the high porosity of MOFs compared to that of traditional solid-state materials, such as zeolite, that drives researchers to this area. Additionally, MOFs can be charge-transferers if proper linkers and transition metals are employed. The self-assembly of metal ions and predefined stereochemical and functional organic building units made it possible to form defined targeted MOFs with diversiform structures of two-dimensional, three-dimensional, or functional MOFs. However, obtaining a precisely controlled structure from the self-assembly process is still a challenge due to the many elements that affect its final structure, such as the structure of the ligands, type of metal salts, amount of metal/ligand ratio, temperature, etc. Thus, the choice of organic ligands plays a crucial role in designing desirable MOFs because the ligand conformations have significant influence on the final structure, and our group recently studied the effect of solvent polarity on MOFs. The main focus has been on polycarboxylic acids and multiple nitrogenous compounds (for example, imidazole and pyridine) because of the easy formation of coordination bonds; additionally, the combination of these two kinds of ligands has largely enriched the topological world.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A large amount of attention has been widely focused on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in many areas, ranging from catalysis to surface chemistry, gas storage and separation, sensing, ion exchange, drug delivery, carbon capture, and magnetic materials. This attention is due to their unique, interesting topological structures and fascinating properties, such as facile synthesis, large surface area, and relatively high thermal stability and porosity; among these, it is the high porosity of MOFs compared to that of traditional solid-state materials, such as zeolite, that drives researchers to this area. Additionally, MOFs can be charge-transferers if proper linkers and transition metals are employed. The self-assembly of metal ions and predefined stereochemical and functional organic building units made it possible to form defined targeted MOFs with diversiform structures of two-dimensional, three-dimensional, or functional MOFs. However, obtaining a precisely controlled structure from the self-assembly process is still a challenge due to the many elements that affect its final structure, such as the structure of the ligands, type of metal salts, amount of metal/ligand ratio, temperature, etc. Thus, the choice of organic ligands plays a crucial role in designing desirable MOFs because the ligand conformations have significant influence on the final structure, and our group recently studied the effect of solvent polarity on MOFs. The main focus has been on polycarboxylic acids and multiple nitrogenous compounds (for example, imidazole and pyridine) because of the easy formation of coordination bonds; additionally, the combination of these two kinds of ligands has largely enriched the topological world.

elements.content: cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4-Cyclopentaneteracarboxylic acid (H4L) exhibits mutual mirror images (enantiomers). These enantiomers may appear in the process of conformation conversion. H4L is a flexible acid ligand in which the four carbolic group can easily reverse. There are 10 possible conformations of H4L ligands, as shown in .
elements.clean_text: cis,cis,cis,cis-1,2,3,4-Cyclopentaneteracarboxylic acid (H4L) exhibits mutual mirror images (enantiomers). These enantiomers may appear in the process of conformation conversion. H4L is a flexible acid ligand in which the four carbolic group can easily reverse. There are 10 possible conformations of H4L ligands, as shown in .

elements.content: We have already reported three isostructural compounds constructed by the flexible acid ligand H4L (metal: cobalt and zinc) with a 1-dimensional chain structure. The special feature of these structures is their isolated metal ions (Co2+ and Zn2+) which coordinate with six water molecules. The compounds form 2-dimensional layers through water-coordinated metal ions via hydrogen bonds as shown in .
elements.clean_text: We have already reported three isostructural compounds constructed by the flexible acid ligand H4L (metal: cobalt and zinc) with a 1-dimensional chain structure. The special feature of these structures is their isolated metal ions (Co2+ and Zn2+) which coordinate with six water molecules. The compounds form 2-dimensional layers through water-coordinated metal ions via hydrogen bonds as shown in .

elements.content: Structure of the compounds of H4L and metal ions (Co2+ and Zn2+) (the red molecules show the six coordinated metal ions with water molecules).
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of the compounds of H4L and metal ions (Co2+ and Zn2+) (the red molecules show the six coordinated metal ions with water molecules).

elements.content: If linear bidentate N-ligands are added in this situation, we suppose that the N-ligands will replace the isolated metal ions of the complex and form 2- or 3-dimensional porous frameworks (). We also considered changing the features (length, shape, etc.) of the N-ligands, which would adjust the pore features of the frameworks. We used five N-ligands (bpy, bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip) () coordinated with H4L and Co­(II) salt, and five new compounds were obtained, namely, {[Co2L­(bpy)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (1), {[Co2L­(pbyb)0.5(H2O)2]·3H2O} n (2), {[Co2L­(dpe)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (3), {[Co2L­(dpa)0.5(H2O)2]·2.5H2O} n (4), and {[Co2L­(dip)0.5(H2O)2]·3.5H2O} n (5).
elements.clean_text: If linear bidentate N-ligands are added in this situation, we suppose that the N-ligands will replace the isolated metal ions of the complex and form 2- or 3-dimensional porous frameworks (). We also considered changing the features (length, shape, etc.) of the N-ligands, which would adjust the pore features of the frameworks. We used five N-ligands (bpy, bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip) () coordinated with H4L and Co(II) salt, and five new compounds were obtained, namely, {[Co2L(bpy)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1), {[Co2L(pbyb)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3H2O} n  (2), {[Co2L(dpe)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (3), {[Co2L(dpa)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O} n  (4), and {[Co2L(dip)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} n  (5).

elements.content: Single crystals of compounds 1–5 were prepared via hydrothermal reaction of H4L, N-ligands, and cobalt nitrate. The pH was controlled at ≈4.0 by the addition of several drops of a 3% (w/w) NaOH solution. The obtained samples are highly reproducible. The details are provided in the .
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Single crystals of compounds 1-5 were prepared via hydrothermal reaction of H4L, N-ligands, and cobalt nitrate. The pH was controlled at ~4.0 by the addition of several drops of a 3% (w/w) NaOH solution. The obtained samples are highly reproducible. The details are provided in the .

elements.content: X-ray analysis revealed that 1–5 are isostructural and crystallize in the triclinic crystal with space group P1̅ (). As shown in , 1 consists of one Co1 ion, one-half of a Co2 ion, one-half of a Co3 ion, one deprotonated L4–, one bpy ligand, two coordinated H2O molecules, and two free H2O molecules. The coordination number of the three different Co­(II) centers is six. The Co1 atom coordinates to one nitrogen atom of the bpy ligand and five oxygen atoms from the three L4– ligands, and the coordination geometry is a distorted octahedron. The distance of Co1–N is 2.0561(18) Å. The distance of Co1–O is between 2.0475(17) and 2.2978(19) Å. The angles of N–Co1–O are between 92.70(8)° and 155.35(7)°. The angles of O–Co1–O are between 58.30(6)° and 156.29(6)°. Both of the Co2 and Co3 ions are located at an inversion center. The Co2 atom coordinates to six carboxylate oxygen atoms from the L4– ligands. In this case, the coordination octahedron is symmetric with a Co2–O distance of 2.0646(17)–2.0780(17) Å; O–Co2–O angles are in the range of 84.66(6)–90.14(6)°, and the O–Co2–O angles between two trans-O atoms and Co2 are 180°. The coordination environment of the Co3 atom is similar to that of the Co2 atom. A regular octahedron forms by the connection of four oxygen atoms from four H2O molecules and two oxygen atoms from two L4– ligands. The distance of Co3–O ranges from 2.1044(21) to 2.1182(18) Å, and the angles of O–Co3–O are in the range of 86.36(7)–100.13(6)°. Compounds 2–5 connect in a similar way with the pyridine ligands replaced by bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, respectively ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure of [Co2L(bpy)⋅4H2O] n  (1)

X-ray analysis revealed that 1-5 are isostructural and crystallize in the triclinic crystal with space group P1̅ (). As shown in , 1 consists of one Co1 ion, one-half of a Co2 ion, one-half of a Co3 ion, one deprotonated L4-, one bpy ligand, two coordinated H2O molecules, and two free H2O molecules. The coordination number of the three different Co(II) centers is six. The Co1 atom coordinates to one nitrogen atom of the bpy ligand and five oxygen atoms from the three L4- ligands, and the coordination geometry is a distorted octahedron. The distance of Co1-N is 2.0561(18) Å. The distance of Co1-O is between 2.0475(17) and 2.2978(19) Å. The angles of N-Co1-O are between 92.70(8)° and 155.35(7)°. The angles of O-Co1-O are between 58.30(6)° and 156.29(6)°. Both of the Co2 and Co3 ions are located at an inversion center. The Co2 atom coordinates to six carboxylate oxygen atoms from the L4- ligands. In this case, the coordination octahedron is symmetric with a Co2-O distance of 2.0646(17)-2.0780(17) Å; O-Co2-O angles are in the range of 84.66(6)-90.14(6)°, and the O-Co2-O angles between two trans-O atoms and Co2 are 180°. The coordination environment of the Co3 atom is similar to that of the Co2 atom. A regular octahedron forms by the connection of four oxygen atoms from four H2O molecules and two oxygen atoms from two L4- ligands. The distance of Co3-O ranges from 2.1044(21) to 2.1182(18) Å, and the angles of O-Co3-O are in the range of 86.36(7)-100.13(6)°. Compounds 2-5 connect in a similar way with the pyridine ligands replaced by bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, respectively ().

elements.content: Coordination environment of the Co­(II) ions in 1. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (#1) 1 + x, y, z; (#2) 1 – x, 2 – y, −z; (#3) 2 – x, 1 – y, −z; (#4) 1 – x, 3 – y, 1 – z.
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination environment of the Co(II) ions in 1. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (#1) 1 + x, y, z; (#2) 1 - x, 2 - y, -z; (#3) 2 - x, 1 - y, -z; (#4) 1 - x, 3 - y, 1 - z.

elements.content: Trinuclear Co2+ clusters (Co3L2) form by the connection of oxygen atoms from two L4– ligands, one Co2 atom, and two Co1 atoms, and the L4– ligand shows a μ4, k6 mode. Along the b-axis direction, Co3L2 clusters connect to the neighboring Co3L2 clusters to form a cobalt chain (a). These chains are further connected by {Co3(H2O)4} clusters via Co–O–C bonds, forming 2-dimensional layers (b). In contrast to the already reported structure, without pyridine ligands, Co3 coordinated with six water molecules forms isolated {Co3(H2O)6} clusters. These 2-dimensional layers stack together layer-by-layer through inserting pillars (pyridine ligands); a porous 3-dimensional framework with open channels along the b-axis is the result (c).
elements.clean_text: Trinuclear Co2+ clusters (Co3L2) form by the connection of oxygen atoms from two L4- ligands, one Co2 atom, and two Co1 atoms, and the L4- ligand shows a μ4, k6 mode. Along the b-axis direction, Co3L2 clusters connect to the neighboring Co3L2 clusters to form a cobalt chain (a). These chains are further connected by {Co3(H2O)4} clusters via Co-O-C bonds, forming 2-dimensional layers (b). In contrast to the already reported structure, without pyridine ligands, Co3 coordinated with six water molecules forms isolated {Co3(H2O)6} clusters. These 2-dimensional layers stack together layer-by-layer through inserting pillars (pyridine ligands); a porous 3-dimensional framework with open channels along the b-axis is the result (c).

elements.content: (a) Coordination of the 1-dimensional chain connected by L4–, bpy ligands, and the Co­(II) ion in 1. (b) 2-dimensional layers in 1. (c) 3-dimensional framework of 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination of the 1-dimensional chain connected by L4-, bpy ligands, and the Co(II) ion in 1. (b) 2-dimensional layers in 1. (c) 3-dimensional framework of 1.

elements.content: The L4– ligands in 1 maintain the original SSRR configuration and adopt μ5 coordination modes with four carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η1-syn-syn, μ2-η1:η1-syn-anti, μ1-η1:η0-monodentate, and μ2-η1:η2-chelating bridging modes ( and ). L4– ligands in 2–5 show the same configuration as 1. However, the L4– ligands in 1, 2, and 4 show mirror coordination symmetry while those in 3 and 5 do not, as shown in and . The resulting mirror coordination clusters of {Co5L} n have interesting structures, which is a rare phenomenon in coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: The L4- ligands in 1 maintain the original SSRR configuration and adopt μ5 coordination modes with four carboxylate groups in μ2-η1:η1-syn-syn, μ2-η1:η1-syn-anti, μ1-η1:η0-monodentate, and μ2-η1:η2-chelating bridging modes ( and ). L4- ligands in 2-5 show the same configuration as 1. However, the L4- ligands in 1, 2, and 4 show mirror coordination symmetry while those in 3 and 5 do not, as shown in  and . The resulting mirror coordination clusters of {Co5L} n  have interesting structures, which is a rare phenomenon in coordination polymers.

elements.content: Conformations of H4L ligands in 1–5. Note: 1, 2, and 4 and 3 and 5 are mirror image symmetry.
elements.clean_text: 4  Conformations of H4L ligands in 1-5. Note: 1, 2, and 4 and 3 and 5 are mirror image symmetry.

elements.content: Schematic view of coordination modes of H4L ligands in 1–5. Note: A and B are mirror coordination clusters.
elements.clean_text: 5  Schematic view of coordination modes of H4L ligands in 1-5. Note: A and B are mirror coordination clusters.

elements.content: When bpy in 1 is replaced by bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, we obtained the isomorphic 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively. The structures of these compounds are similar to that of 1 with a linear trinuclear cluster (Co3L2) 1-dimensional chain along the b-axis direction. The chains are connected by two oxygen atoms from two L4– ligands coordinated to one Co3 atom to form 2-dimensional sheets, and N-ligands link the 2-dimensional sheets to form a 3-dimensional framework with 1-dimensional channel pores. It is worth mentioning that the channel pore features are different, as shown in and . The lengths of the N-ligands are 9.5844(44), 11.4239(3), 9.4032(31), 10.2211(92), and 9.880(3) Å for bpy, bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, respectively. The distances between layers are 11.2599(5), 15.5557(8), 13.5321(9), 13.1591(15), and 13.6309(6) Å, respectively. The distances between the layers of compounds 1–5 do not match well with the lengths of the N-ligands, which is due to the different angles of the connecting layers of the N-ligands (α). The α values are 74.2°, 75.8°, 71.2°, 69.9°, and 88.7° for bpy, bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, respectively. The bpy and bpyb molecules are the two coordinated N-atoms on the center line of the molecules (β, the angle between the line of the two coordinated N-atoms and the center line), although with different molecular lengths, that show almost the same α angle (74.2° and 75.8°, respectively). The dpe and dpa molecules are similar in structure and have similar β angles (7.6° and 8.3°, respectively) and α angles (71.2° and 69.9°, respectively). For dip molecules, which are imidazoles, β is 14.5°, and when compared to the four pyridine ligands, the dip molecules show the largest α angle of 88.7°.
elements.clean_text: When bpy in 1 is replaced by bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, we obtained the isomorphic 2, 3, 4, and 5, respectively. The structures of these compounds are similar to that of 1 with a linear trinuclear cluster (Co3L2) 1-dimensional chain along the b-axis direction. The chains are connected by two oxygen atoms from two L4- ligands coordinated to one Co3 atom to form 2-dimensional sheets, and N-ligands link the 2-dimensional sheets to form a 3-dimensional framework with 1-dimensional channel pores. It is worth mentioning that the channel pore features are different, as shown in  and . The lengths of the N-ligands are 9.5844(44), 11.4239(3), 9.4032(31), 10.2211(92), and 9.880(3) Å for bpy, bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, respectively. The distances between layers are 11.2599(5), 15.5557(8), 13.5321(9), 13.1591(15), and 13.6309(6) Å, respectively. The distances between the layers of compounds 1-5 do not match well with the lengths of the N-ligands, which is due to the different angles of the connecting layers of the N-ligands (α). The α values are 74.2°, 75.8°, 71.2°, 69.9°, and 88.7° for bpy, bpyb, dpe, dpa, and dip, respectively. The bpy and bpyb molecules are the two coordinated N-atoms on the center line of the molecules (β, the angle between the line of the two coordinated N-atoms and the center line), although with different molecular lengths, that show almost the same α angle (74.2° and 75.8°, respectively). The dpe and dpa molecules are similar in structure and have similar β angles (7.6° and 8.3°, respectively) and α angles (71.2° and 69.9°, respectively). For dip molecules, which are imidazoles, β is 14.5°, and when compared to the four pyridine ligands, the dip molecules show the largest α angle of 88.7°.

Plots of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1–5 are shown in . For 1, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 7.05%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 7.05%) is 14.15% between 50 and 175 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 362 °C. For 2, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.32%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 9.47%) is 15.79% between 50 and 170 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 350 °C. For 3, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%) is 13.65% between 50 and 160 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 389 °C. For 4, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.70%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%) is 15.08% between 50 and 160 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 339 °C. For 5, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.33%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 11.07%) is 17.50% between 25 and 240 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 413 °C. The results show that the frameworks of the five compounds are thermally stable. Compound 5 has the highest thermal stability of the five compounds. PXRD analyses of compounds 1–5 were carried out. As shown in , the experimental spectra of 1–5 are almost the same as the simulated spectra.

Thermogravimetric and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Analyses

Plots of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1-5 are shown in . For 1, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 7.05%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 7.05%) is 14.15% between 50 and 175 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 362 °C. For 2, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.32%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 9.47%) is 15.79% between 50 and 170 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 350 °C. For 3, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%) is 13.65% between 50 and 160 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 389 °C. For 4, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.70%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 6.83%) is 15.08% between 50 and 160 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 339 °C. For 5, the weight loss of the free H2O molecules (calcd 6.33%) and the coordinated H2O molecules (calcd 11.07%) is 17.50% between 25 and 240 °C. The framework decomposes quickly after the temperature reaches 413 °C. The results show that the frameworks of the five compounds are thermally stable. Compound 5 has the highest thermal stability of the five compounds. PXRD analyses of compounds 1-5 were carried out. As shown in , the experimental spectra of 1-5 are almost the same as the simulated spectra.

elements.content: shows plots of the temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities (χM T ∼ T) of 1–5. At room temperature, for two magnetically isolated spin-only Co­(II) ions where S = 3/2 and g = 2.0, the theoretical χM T value is 3.75 cm3 K mol–1. At 300 K, the χM T values are 5.95, 5.76, 5.60, 5.65, and 5.45 cm3 K mol–1 for 1–5, respectively. This high experimental χM T value may be due to the significant orbital contribution of the Co­(II) ions. As the temperature decreases from 300 to 2 K, the χM T value decreases; at 8 K, the χM T values reach local minimums of 2.02, 1.68, 1.75, 1.76, and 2.15 cm3 K mol–1 for 1–5, respectively. The results suggest that these compounds exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of 1-5 

  shows plots of the temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities (χM T ~ T) of 1-5. At room temperature, for two magnetically isolated spin-only Co(II) ions where S = 3/2 and g = 2.0, the theoretical χM T value is 3.75 cm3 K mol-1. At 300 K, the χM T values are 5.95, 5.76, 5.60, 5.65, and 5.45 cm3 K mol-1 for 1-5, respectively. This high experimental χM T value may be due to the significant orbital contribution of the Co(II) ions. As the temperature decreases from 300 to 2 K, the χM T value decreases; at 8 K, the χM T values reach local minimums of 2.02, 1.68, 1.75, 1.76, and 2.15 cm3 K mol-1 for 1-5, respectively. The results suggest that these compounds exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of compounds 1–5.
elements.clean_text: 7  Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of compounds 1-5.

elements.content: There are strong spin–orbital coupling interactions between Co2+ ions of compounds 1–5. We tried several formulas to fit the plots of χM T ∼ T but failed. When the experimental data for 1/χM vs T between 25 and 300 K were fitted according to the Curie–Weiss law, we obtained the following parameters: C = 6.55, 5.86, 6.11, 7.33, and 5.82 cm3 K mol–1 for 1–5, respectively. θ = −21.73, −24.90, −24.71, −25.66, and −22.93 K for 1–5, respectively. The negative θ values also suggest the weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compounds 1–5.
elements.clean_text: There are strong spin-orbital coupling interactions between Co2+ ions of compounds 1-5. We tried several formulas to fit the plots of χM T ~ T but failed. When the experimental data for 1/χM vs T between 25 and 300 K were fitted according to the Curie-Weiss law, we obtained the following parameters: C = 6.55, 5.86, 6.11, 7.33, and 5.82 cm3 K mol-1 for 1-5, respectively. θ = -21.73, -24.90, -24.71, -25.66, and -22.93 K for 1-5, respectively. The negative θ values also suggest the weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compounds 1-5.

elements.content: In summary, five isomorphic metal–organic frameworks with formulas {[Co2L­(bpy)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (1), {[Co2L­(pbyb)0.5(H2O)2]·3H2O} n (2), {[Co2L­(dpe)0.5(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (3), {[Co2L­(dpa)0.5(H2O)2]·2.5H2O} n (4), and {[Co2L­(dip)0.5(H2O)2]·3.5H2O} n (5) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The L4– ligand maintains its original conformation in all of these compounds, but {Co5L} n clusters show mirror coordination symmetry in 1, 2, and 4 while the clusters in 3 and 5 do not. The addition of different N-ligands can tune the distance between {Co2L} n layers and change the pore structures of the frameworks. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that 1–5 exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, five isomorphic metal-organic frameworks with formulas {[Co2L(bpy)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1), {[Co2L(pbyb)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3H2O} n  (2), {[Co2L(dpe)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (3), {[Co2L(dpa)0.5(H2O)2]⋅2.5H2O} n  (4), and {[Co2L(dip)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} n  (5) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. The L4- ligand maintains its original conformation in all of these compounds, but {Co5L} n  clusters show mirror coordination symmetry in 1, 2, and 4 while the clusters in 3 and 5 do not. The addition of different N-ligands can tune the distance between {Co2L} n  layers and change the pore structures of the frameworks. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that 1-5 exhibit antiferromagnetic behavior.

metadata.title:
Cyclopentaneteracarboxylic Metal–Organic Frameworks:
Tuning the Distance between Layers and Pore Structures with N‑Ligands
